titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Western Film Lobby Card and Poster Collection
Western Film Lobby Card and Poster Collection
titlestmt.author: by Jennifer Meehan, David Williams, and Santana Haight

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 03:36

did.unittitle: Western film lobby card and poster collection

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The collection consists primarily of lobby cards, posters, and promotional fliers, relating to western films made from 1916 to the 1980s. There are also some pressbooks and photographs in the collection. Represented within the collection are works by notable directors, such as John Ford, Howard Hawks, Allan Dwan, Henry King, Billy Wilder, Roman Polanski, William S. Hart, Sergio Leone, André de Toth, Nicholas Ray, Raoul Walsh, Anthony Mann, and Sam Peckinpah. Also represented are works featuring notable western stars, such as William S. Hart, William Boyd as Hopalong Cassidy, Gene Autry, Roy Rogers, Buck Jones, and Harry Carey, among others. Highlights include original posters for Stagecoach (1939), directed by John Ford, and the original poster for the Italian release of Per qualche dollaro in più (For a Few Dollars More) (1965).

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The collection was purchased from WalterFilm.com on the Arthur Corbitt Hoskins Memorial Fund in 2007. Additional material acquired through gift and purchase from Walter Reuben, 2011-2012.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Western Film Lobby Card and Poster Collection is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Western Film Lobby Card and Poster Collection. Yale Collection of Western Americana, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and organization. Descriptive information is drawn in large part from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles were supplied by staff during initial processing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of primarily of lobby cards, posters, and promotional fliers, relating to western films made from 1916 to the 1980s. There are also some pressbooks and photographs in the collection. Represented within the collection are works by notable directors, such as John Ford, Howard Hawks, Allan Dwan, Henry King, Billy Wilder, Roman Polanski, William S. Hart, Sergio Leone, André de Toth, Nicholas Ray, Raoul Walsh, Anthony Mann, and Sam Peckinpah. Also represented are works featuring notable western stars, such as William S. Hart, William Boyd as Hopalong Cassidy, Gene Autry, Roy Rogers, Buck Jones, and Harry Carey, among others. Highlights include original posters for Stagecoach (1939), directed by John Ford, and the original poster for the Italian release of Per qualche dollaro in più (For a Few Dollars More) (1965).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Material is arranged alphabetically by film title. Larger oversize and rolled items have been physically organized at the end. They are listed alphabetically with a note about their physical location and at the end where they are physically located.

controlaccess.title: Per qualche dollaro in più (Motion picture)
Stagecoach (Motion picture : 1939)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Billy Wilder's truculent film, about a vicious newspaper reporter, exiled for his previous bad behavior, to a miserable southwestern town, who takes advantage of a mining accident, with eventual tragic results. One of the classics of 50's film noir.

did.unittitle: Billy the Kid, photograph (8" x 10") with printed note on verso

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Directed by King Vidor. In this version of the Billy the Kid legend, Billy, after shooting down land baron William Donovan's henchmen for killing Billy's boss, is hunted down and captured by his friend, Sheriff Pat Garrett. He escapes and is on his way to Mexico when Garrett, recapturing him, must decide whether to bring him in or to let him go. This was only director King Vidor's second talking film, and histories of the western cite it as one of the really important early talkies in the genre.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Buck Jones western.

odd.p: Buster Crabbe PRC western.

did.unittitle: Blazing Overland Trail, poster for Chapter One of a western serial

odd.head: General note
odd.p: "Easterner Keith Whitney, son of a wealthy Senator, heads west where he ends up a drunk at a border cafe. After losing the money his father sent him to buy a ranch he learns his father is arriving. Rancher Tex now takes him in and tells his father he is part owner. When his father and girlfriend are kidnaped, Tex and a now reformed Keith take out after them." (www.imdb.com) Harry Carey western.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Anthony Mann film noir about the smuggling into California of illegal aliens. Mann started his directing career with films noir, and then followed up with ten years of classic westerns, mostly with James Stewart, and this was a sort of transition film between the two genres.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: George O'Brien western.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Bob Steele Republic B-western.

odd.head: General note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Rare slide, used to promote the film in small theatres at the time of its original release. Contains artwork montage of scenes from the film, including one of the young Kane with his sled "Rosebud" at the bottom left.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Promotional yearbook, which contains a full page devoted to Citizen Kane under its early working title "John Citizen, U.S.A."

odd.head: General note
odd.p: This is an important piece---for a western film both starring and directed by the legendary William S. Hart, an unusual and, sadly, apparently lost film, in which he plays a person half white and half native American. This was a remarkable early effort in silent cinema to portray native people with some depth.

odd.p: This card is one of a handful of westerns produced during the short-lived "3-D" craze of 1953-1954, and it has border artwork reflecting the three-dimensional gimmick.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: The Lone Ranger was featured for many years in a radio show, then in a popular televisison show, and this film featured the cast of the television show, most notably Clayton Moore in the title role.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Ronald Reagan western, which is of interest because, when he started his political career campaigning for governor of California in the 1960's, he was clearly running on a "law and order" platform.

did.unittitle: Law of the Barbary Coast, title lobby card
Law of the Texan, poster, on linen

odd.head: General note
odd.p: A Buck Jones western gets here very interesting pulp artwork.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: A good representation of John Wayne's early journeyman career. From 1930, when he made his effective debut in Raoul Walsh's THE BIG TRAIL, until 1939, when John Ford's STAGECOACH revitalized both the film western and Wayne's career, he worked in numerous B-movies. This is an excellent example of one of those, a dramatic scene with close shot of Wayne grabbing a bandit with his left hand as he points his gun at him with his right hand.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Ken Maynard Columbia western.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Very rare Columbia Records poster for Bob Dylan soundtrack. Heartbreaking revisionist western, recently restored, with Kris Kristofferson and James Coburn. Elaborate photomontage has five images of Bob Dylan and at least four of Sam Peckinpah.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Alfred Hitchcock directed film, based on the novel by Robert Bloch, starring Anthony Perkins and Janet Leigh.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Raoul Walsh's western with Robert Mitchum is an extraordinarily important film---almost certainly the first western to incorporate visual and thematic elements of film noir, and also one of the earliest western films to make use of Freudian psychology in its rather twisted flashback-ridden plot.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Western adventure film, adapted from Jack London.

did.unittitle: Rebel Without a Cause, photographs (8" x 10", set of 12)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: James Dean film, directed by Nicholas Ray.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Bob Allen in Columbia film.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Portrait of John Wayne and Montgomery Clift from Howard Hawks epic western classic. This photo has typed studio text on back, and was obviously used for publication at the time of the film's original release.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Artwork for Tim McCoy B-western for Columbia.

did.unittitle: Ride the High Country, color stills (8" x 10", set of 12)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Sam Peckinpah's elegiac western starred two aging icons of the genre, Randolph Scott and Joel McCrea, in his second feature and his first masterpiece.

did.unittitle: Ridin' Down the Canyon, lobby card

odd.head: General note
odd.p: An Andre deToth western with Randolph Scott. In recent years, critics have belatedly discovered deToth's films, including this one.

did.unittitle: Rim of the Canyon, lobby card

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Another important late western from director Allan Dwan.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Randolph Scott western produced by Harry Joe Brown---early in a series of films where Brown would soon bring in Budd Boetticher to direct. This was the first collaboration of Scott with Brown.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: John Wayne in John Ford Western.

odd.head: General note

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Classic western comedy by Frank Tashlin, then early in his directing career, who was a favorite director of the French New Wave.

odd.head: General note

did.unittitle: Stagecoach, window card poster, paper backed and Promotional flyer, 12mo, 4 pp.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Extremely rare original poster for legendary John Ford film, in which he returned, after many years, to the western and, in some sense, reinvented it, and , in the process, made a genuine star of John Wayne.
Promotional flyer contains a map of the route followed by the stagecoach as well as portraits of some of the film's main stars.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Reagan played a horse doctor in rural southern California, in one of his favorite films.

did.unittitle: Story of Will Rogers, lobby card

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Film noir, set in Southern California.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Silent Rex Bell western.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Classic Allan Dwan western adapted from story by Bret Harte. Dwan's career spanned all the way back to working with D.W. Griffith in the teens. He made many important films in the 20's and 30's, but, by the 50's, he was a forgotten man, and he actually made many of the films which critics rate most highly in those years, on low budgets, such as this one.

did.unittitle: Terror of Bar X, lobby cards

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Bob Custer silent western, this card has unusually bright hand coloring and vivid border art design.

did.unittitle: They Came to Cordura, photograph (8" x 10")

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Robert Rossen film set in the Mexican desert during World War I.

did.unittitle: They Came to Cordura, title lobby card
They Died With Their Boots On, lobby card

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Raoul Walsh film about Custer and Little Big Horn. This is a particularly interesting image of the Native Americans on the warpath.

did.unittitle: Those Redheads from Seattle, lobby cards

odd.head: General note
odd.p: 3-D western musical romance.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: John Wayne film set in North Dakota and Oregon, which traces some of the same themes as The Grapes of Wrath, which was released in the same year.

did.unittitle: A Ticket to Tomahawk, lobby card (11" x 14")

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Marilyn Monroe western.

did.unittitle: Tortilla Flat, photographs (8" x 10"), double weight, date stamped, with printed text on verso

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Photographs by the Hollywood photographer Clarence S. Bull, with his stamps also on verso. John Steinbeck's books, most of them set in the West, were the sources for a number of important Hollywood films, including this one.

did.unittitle: Tracked by the Police, lobby card

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Rin Tin Tin drama set in Arizona. In the silent era, dog star Rin Tin Tin captured the imagination of movie audiences with dramas, most of which, like this one, were set in western locales.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Tom Mix silent film.

did.unittitle: The Traveling Saleswoman, title lobby card

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Grand National film starring Tex Ritter and a very young Rita Hayworth, who was still being billed as Rita Cansino. An iconic closeup of cowboy Ritter and Hayworth.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Charles Starrett western.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Cecil B. DeMille film.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Tom Tyler western.
